Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns, (b) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, (c) NH3-TPD curves and (d) Py-IR spectra of the samples after evacuation at 150 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) TS-1-M, (b) ZSM-5-M and (c) Silicalite-1-M samples. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the (a) calcined and (b) reduced Ni catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a) Ni/TS-1-M, (b) Ni/ZSM-5-M and (c) Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the series of Ni catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Ni 2p XPS spectra for the fresh reduced catalysts (a) Ni/TS-1-M, (b) Ni/ZSM-5-M, (c) Ni/Silicalite-1-M, (d) Ti 2p XPS spectra for the TS-1-M and fresh reduced Ni/TS-1-M samples. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) NH3-TPD curves, and Py-IR spectra of catalysts evaluated at (b) 150 °C and (c) 260 °C. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Palmitic acid conversion and product selectivity versus reaction time in palmitic acid HDO on (a) Ni/TS-1-M, (b) Ni/Silicalite-1-M, (c) Ni/TiO2 and (d) Ni/ZSM-5-M catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) Ni 2p XPS spectrum for the fresh reduced Ni/TS-1-M-94 catalyst, (b) Ti 2p XPS spectra for the TS-1-M-94 and fresh reduced Ni/TS-1-M-94 samples, (c) Ni 2p XPS spectrum for the fresh reduced 3Ni/TS-1-M catalyst, (d) Ti 2p XPS spectra for the TS-1-M and fresh reduced 3Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The interaction of the TiO6 octahedron in the TS-1-M zeolite with Ni species promoting the charge transfer. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The percentage of the reactants (palmitic acid and HOL) and product in the reaction systems over (a) TS-1-M, (b) Silicalite-1-M and (c) TiO2 catalysts (PP percentage =carbon moles of PP/the initial carbon moles of PA and HOL, PA percentage =carbon moles of PA/the initial carbon moles of PA and HOL, HOL percentage =carbon moles of HOL/the initial carbon moles of PA and HOL). Dalian 116045 China SINOPEC Dalian Research Institute of Petroleum and Petrochemicals Co., Ltd., Dalian 116045, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Developing a highly efficient Ni-based hydrodeoxygenation catalyst is crucial for the production of renewable biodiesel. Herein, a mesoporous TS-1 zeolite supported Ni catalyst (Ni/TS-1-M) exhibited exceptional hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity and achieved 100 % yield of deoxygenated hydrocarbons (97.3 % pentadecane vs 2.7 % hexadecane), outperforming other catalysts such as Ni on mesoporous ZSM-5 (Ni/ZSM-5-M), mesoporous Silicalite-1 (Ni/Silicalite-1-M) and TiO2 (Ni/TiO2). The Ti(IV) atoms in the form of TiO4 and TiO6 can transfer its electron to nearby metal Ni, leading to the increase in electron density of metal Ni, which enhanced the hydrogenation activity and facilitated the C–C bond cleavage of the hexadecanal to produce pentadecane. Furthermore, the framework Ti(IV) species accelerated the esterification process to generate palmityl palmitate, which was easily hydrogenolyzed to the main intermediate of hexadecanol under the synergistic effect of metal Ni and Ti(IV) on Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. The formed hexadecanol mainly underwent successive dehydrogenation/decarbonylation process to transform into pentadecane. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mesoporous TS-1 zeolite Ni-based catalyst Framework Ti(IV) Palmitic acid Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biofuel generated from renewable energy sources have gained significant attention due to its carbon neutrality and environmental benignity, making it a promising alternative for fossil fuel [1,2]. Vegetable oils, waste oils/fats, and microalgae oil are examples of triglyceride-based materials that hold great potential as renewable feedstocks for producing biodiesel due to their carbon numbers being similar to those found in petroleum-derived diesel [3–5]. In order to produce high-grade biodiesel, the fatty acids, the major components of triglyceride-based biomass, must undergo deoxygenation process to convert them into diesel-range hydrocarbons, which has been proven to be a crucial method for upgrading biodiesel production to a high-grade level [6,7]. The catalytic hydeoxygenation of fatty acids has been extensively studied over different types of metal catalysts, such as Pt, Pd, Ni, and Mo. It has been reported that there are three reaction routes containing hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), decarbonylation (DCO) and decarboxylation (DCO2) to remove the oxygen as the form of H2O, CO and CO2, respectively [7,8], and the reaction pathways depend strongly on the catalyst composition, which consists of supports and active metals [7,9]. Metal nickel (Ni) species is commonly utilized as an active metal in the preparation of deoxygenation catalysts due to its excellent performance and low cost [10]. It is suggested that the Ni-based catalyst can facilitate the conversion of fatty acids into hydrocarbons through two parallel pathways (HDO and DCO) during the deoxygenation process, which is influenced by the nature of the support [10,11]. Up to now, various types of supports have been used to prepare Ni catalysts to investigate their catalytic performance in the HDO of fatty acids. The Ni-based catalysts supported on metal oxides such as ZrO2, TiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2-ZrO2 were found to predominantly deoxygenate fatty acids through the DCO pathway [10,12]. By contrast, when the Ni catalysts were supported on the acidic aluminosilicate zeolites for the HDO of the fatty acids, the presence of Brønsted acid sites not only strengthen metal-support interaction, enhancing the dispersion of Ni metal, but also promote the dehydration of alcohol intermediates, thereby favoring the HDO pathway [13,14]. Thus, compared to metal oxides, the aluminosilicate zeolites supported Ni catalysts exhibit superior deoxygenation activity. For example, acidic ZSM-5, Beta and USY zeolites provide large specific surface area and expose abundant acidic sites, and the resulting Ni active species on these zeolites are in the form of well-dispersed nanoparticles and demonstrate a better deoxygenation performance [15,16]. However, the excessive acidic sites on aluminosilicate zeolites can also induce excessive cracking of the intermediate and deoxygenation products during the fatty acids HDO process, leading to the catalyst deactivation and lowering the liquid yield [16,17]. To overcome this drawback, developing a high-efficiency Ni-based catalyst by choosing a support with unique properties to alleviate the intermediates cracking is very important for manufacturing biodiesel. Titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) zeolite was a titanosilicate form zeolite with MFI structure, which has the framework Ti species. The Ti species can be present in the formation of defect sites (SiO)3TiOH and (SiO)3Ti(OH)2, leading to the characteristic of weak acid [18]. The special framework Ti(IV) species in TS-1 zeolite make this zeolite exhibit excellently selective catalytic oxidation performance in the production of high value-added chemicals [19,20]. On the other hand, it is noted that introducing Ti species in the compositions of the catalyst has beneficial effect on the catalytic performance of the supported metal catalysts. Take an example of metal sulfide (NiMoS) catalyst, the Ti species in the Ti-incorporated SBA-15 and MCM-41 supports could be reduced to Ti3+ species under reaction of H2 atmosphere, of which the spare electrons could be injected into Mo 3d conduction band to weaken the Mo-S interaction [21,22], leading to the creation of more sulfur vacancies and the improvement of desulfurization activity. It has also been reported that the framework Ti(IV) species in TS-1 zeolite can facilitate the sulfidation of the Mo species in the TS-1 supported CoMo catalyst, forming more MoS2 active phases [23]. Thus, a crystalline TS-1 zeolite containing framework Ti could be a good candidate for the preparation of HDO catalyst. The TS-1 zeolite has been used as a support for loading of Ni catalyst for the hydrodeoxygenation of palmitic acid, which investigated the influence of the reaction time, H2 pressure and the valence of active Ni on catalytic performance. It showed that under the optimal experimental conditions (260 °C, 4 MPa, 10 h, 400 rpm), Ni/TS-1 showed catalytic performance than NiO/TS-1 catalyst [24]. Herein, we attempted to utilize mesoporous TS-1 zeolite as a support for the preparation of Ni catalyst (Ni/TS-1-M), which was applied for the HDO of palmitic acid to investigate the effect of the framework Ti(IV) on promoting the enhancement of activity. It was found that the prepared Ni/TS-1-M catalyst exhibited higher catalytic activity and achieved 100 % yield of deoxygenation product, in comparison with the Ni catalysts on mesoporous MFI topology ZSM-5 (Ni/ZSM-5-M), Silicalite-1 (Ni/Silicalite-1-M) and TiO2 (Ni/TiO2). The Ti(IV) species in the Ni/TS-1-M enhanced the electron density of metal Ni through electron transfer from Ti(IV) species to Ni species, leading to the metal Ni with high hydrogenation activity and C-C bond cleavage ability. In addition, the Ti(IV) species facilitated the formation of palmityl palmitate through esterification reaction, and palmityl palmitate was readily hydrogenated to the hexadecanol intermediate under the synergism of the Ni metal and Ti(IV) species on the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material synthesis The mesoporous TS-1 zeolite (TS-1-M) was synthesized by a hydrothermal synthesis method using N,N-dimethyl-N-octadecyl-N-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl) ammonium bromide ([(CH3O)3Si(CH2)3N(CH3)2C18H37]Br, TPOAB) as a meso-template agent according to previous publication [23]. 0.44 g tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) and 19.2 mL tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were mixed under stirring, which was marked as solution A. The mixture solution of 12.8 mL tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH), 9.6 mL isopropanol and 16 mL water was marked as solution B. The solution A was added slowly into the solution B under vigorous stirring. The obtained mixture was further stirring for 2 h at room temperature and then placed at 75 °C for stirring 4 h. Finally, 3.2 mL TPOAB was added dropwise and further stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The obtained gel was transferred into a teflon-coated stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL) for hydrothermal crystallization at 180 °C for 3 days. The obtained sample was filtered, washed, and then dried at 120 °C overnight, and further calcined in air at 550 °C for 4 h. The resulted material was denoted as TS-1-M, and the Si/Ti ratio was 64, determined by X-ray fluorescence spectrum (XRF) on S8 Tiger. The TS-1-M zeolite with low titanium content was synthesized according to the procedure described above, displacing 0.44 g TBOT with 0.29 g TBOT in the gel. The resulting zeolite was denoted as TS-1-M-94, where the 94 represented the Si/Ti ratio determined by XRF. The mesoporous ZSM-5 was synthesized by a traditional hydrothermal synthesis method using an aluminosilicate gel containing TPOAB as a meso-template [25]. Mesoporous Silicalite-1 zeolite was synthesized according to our previous report using silicate gel [26]. The obtained zeolites were denoted as ZSM-5-M and Silicalite-1-M, respectively. The TiO2 was purchased from Sinopharm Reagent Co., LTD. The NiO reference was prepared by high-temperature calcination, namely, a certain amount of nickel nitrate hexahydrate was heated to 500 °C with rate of 2 °C min−1 and maintained at 500 °C for 4 h in air atmosphere (Fig. S1). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalyst with Ni loading of 6 wt% was prepared through incipient wetness impregnation method using nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O) as Ni source. An aqueous solution including a given quantity of nickel nitrate was re-prepared, and this metallic salt solution was impregnated into the powdered support. After that, the wetted samples were placed in atmospheric environment for 10 h and dried at 100 °C for overnight. The dried sample was put in high temperature furnace and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The Ni catalysts supported on TS-1-M, ZSM-5-M, Silicalite-1-M, TS-1-M-94 and TiO2 were named Ni/TS-1-M, Ni/ZSM-5-M, Ni/Silicalite-1-M, Ni/TS-1-M-94 and Ni/TiO2, respectively. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the supports and catalysts were obtained on a RIGAKU Corporation SmartLab with Cu Kα radiation and the range of 5–50°. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were performed on the Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 apparatus at −196 °C. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the samples were carried out on a SUPRA 5 field emission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 5 kV to observe the morphology of samples. The image of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted on a JEM 2100 F microscope. Before observation, the sliced samples were deposited on a copper-grid coated with carbon films. The Si/Ti ratio in TS-1-M zeolite and Si/Al ratio in ZSM-5-M zeolite was 60 and 45, determined by X-ray fluorescence on a Bruker S8 Tiger spectrometer. The ultraviolet–visible diffuse reﬂectance spectrum (UV–vis DRS) was obtained on a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrometer. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was operated on the Micromeritics AutoChem ASAP 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples were first pretreated to remove water and other impurities. After that, calcined samples (30 mg) were loaded in a quartz tube and heated from ambient temperature to 700 °C with a heating rate of 15 °C·min−1 in a mixture gas of H2-Ar (10 vol% H2). The temperature-programmed ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD) of the supports and catalysts were also measured on the same instrument for H2-TPR. A typical run for the supports, 200 mg sample was placed in a quartz tube and pretreated in a helium flow at 550 °C for 2 h. After cooling the sample to 120 °C, a NH3-He mixture gas (10 vol% NH3) was flowed through the sample for 30 min and then switched to helium flow at 120 °C for 2 h. The sample was then heated from 120 °C to 600 °C in He gas at a rate of 10 °C·min−1, and the desorption signal was measured by a TCD. The analysis process of catalyst samples was the same as that for zeolite, except that the catalysts were pre-reduced at 400 °C for 90 min in H2 gas before pretreated in a helium flow. The acidity of the sample was measured on a Bruker TENSOR 27 infrared (IR) spectrophotometer equipped with an in situ reactor cell using pyridine as a probe molecule. Before measurement, the support samples were degassed to 10−2 Pa at 150 °C for 2 h and then cooled to room temperature, and the pyridine vapor was introduced under N2 stream for 30 min. After saturation adsorption, the sample was degassed to 10−2 Pa at 150 °C for 2 h to desorb the physically adsorbed pyridine stream. Then, the pyridine adsorbed IR (Py-IR) spectrum was recorded at room temperature after deduction of the corresponding sample background spectrum. The pyridine adsorbed IR spectrum of the catalyst was obtained using the same operation procedure, except that the catalyst was pre-reduced in H2 at 400 °C for 1 h before degassing. The spectrum of the catalyst was recorded at room temperature in deduction of the sample backing spectrum after desorption of pyridine at 150 °C for 2 h under vacuum of 10−2 Pa. Afterthat, the catalyst was heat to 260 °C under vacuum and maintained at 260 °C for 2 h. When the sample was cooled down to room temperature, the spectrum was recorded. The IR spectra of the palmitic acid adsorbed in zeolite samples were also recorded with Bruker TENSOR 27 infrared spectrometer. Before measurement, the sample was treated by the following procedure: 0.1 g zeolite sample was added in 20 mL n-hexane solution containing 0.05 M palmitic acid under stirring for 12 h at room temperature. Then the solid sample was separated by centrifugation and washed with n-hexane, and dried at 80 °C overnight for IR analysis. The obtained sample was loaded into a cell and then was degassed at 100 °C for 2 h under 10−2 Pa, and the corresponding spectrum was recorded at room temperature after background subtraction. The spectrum of palmitic acid was obtained by the subtraction of KBr background spectrum. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were performed to investigate the chemical valence of metal species on the calcined and reduced catalysts operating on an ESCALAB MK II system. 2.4 Activity test HDO test of palmitic acid: the hydrodeoxygenation of palmitic acid was conducted in a batch autoclave (model 4566) of 300 mL from Parr instrument equipped with a controller model 4848. Before activity evaluation, 0.5 g calcined catalyst was reduced at 450 °C for 4 h under H2 flow with a rate of 100 mL·min−1 and cooled to room temperature naturally. The reduced catalyst was then transferred carefully into decalin solvent (100 mL) in the autoclave under a hydrogen stream. After that, palmitic acid (1.0 g) was added into the autoclave above. The autoclave was sealed, purged three times with H2 to remove air and then heated to target temperature. When the reaction temperature reached 260 °C, the H2 was introduced into autoclave to pressure of 4.0 MPa and the stirring rate was changed into 300 rpm. The liquid samples were collected and analyzed by the Agilent 7890B GC equipped with hydrogen a flame ion detector (FID). During the reaction, the H2 pressure in the autoclave should be always kept at 4 MPa. The carbon balance refers to the conservation of carbon atoms before and after the reaction in one chemical reaction. That is, the initial carbon moles of the reactant such as palmitic acid should be equal to the total carbon moles of the unconverted reactant and formed products. In the palmitic acid HDO reaction, to verify the carbon balance, the conversion (c) and product selectivity (s) are determined by the following equations: (1) c = M y − M t M y × 100 % (2) s = M x i M y − M t where the M y is the initial carbon moles of reactant, M t is the carbon moles of reactant at t h, and M xi is the carbon moles of the product x i. In Eq. (2), it was assumed that the loss carbon numbers from CO2 and CO was negligible. The HDO activity data over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst under the N2 and H2 atmosphere exhibited that both DCO2 and DCO pathways occurred over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst under H2 atmosphere (Fig. S2 and S3, and Table S1, the detailed discussions please see supporting information). Transformation of palmitic acid and hexadecanol: these experiments were also conducted in 300 mL autoclave reactor, and the reaction conditions and procedures were the same as the palmitic acid hydrodeoxygenation described above, except that the metal-free supports (TS-1-M, ZSM-5-M, Silicalite-1-M and TiO2) were used as catalysts, and 0.5 g each of palmitic acid and hexadecanol were used in the experiment. Transformation of palmityl palmitate: to investigate the transformation pathway of palmityl palmitate promoted by Ti(IV) over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst, the reactions were performed by using supports as catalysts. The reaction conditions were identical to that of the palmitic acid HDO described above. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Support characterization XRD patterns of the TS-1-M, ZSM-5-M and Silicalite-1-M zeolites exhibited obviously characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=7.9, 8.8, 23.1, 23.9, 24.4, 45.1 and 45.5° associated with MFI structure in the range of 5–50°, and the TiO2 had the distinct diffraction peaks in the range of 5–50° related to the structure of TiO2 ( Fig. 1a) [27]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of TS-1-M and ZSM-5-M samples exhibited type IV isotherms with H4 hysteresis loops in the range of P/P0=0.40–0.95, while the isotherms of Silicalite-1-M had a hysteresis loop in the range of P/P0=0.10–0.75 (Fig. 1b), indicating that the mesopore size of TS-1-M and ZSM-5-M was larger than that of Silicalite-1-M sample. The pore size distribution demonstrated that the TS-1-M and ZSM-5-M had larger pore size (10.4 and 12.4 nm) than Silicalite-1-M (2.3 nm). In addition, the H4 hysteresis loop indicated that the plate-like slit pore or narrow fissure pores could be present in all samples, and these pore structures were irregular. The sample textural parameters showed that the TS-1-M had slightly higher surface area and mesoporous volume than ZSM-5-M and Silicalite-1-M (Table S2). The NH3-TPD curves showed that NH3 desorption signal of ZSM-5-M mainly appeared in the 120–400 °C temperature region and centered at 245 °C (Fig. 1c), indicating that the ZSM-5-M exhibited large weak acid densities (281.7 μmol·g−1, Table S3). In contrast, the TS-1-M (22.8 μmol·g−1, Table S3) and Silicalite-1-M (6.8 μmol·g−1, Table S3) almost had very little acidities. It is noted that the desorption temperature of NH3 over TiO2 was ranged in 120–500 °C (Fig. 1c), suggested that TiO2 had weak acidic sites with total density of 146.5 μmol·g−1. The Py-IR spectra (Fig. 1d) showed that ZSM-5-M and TS-1-M had Brønsted and Lewis acid sites with the bands at 1546 and 1448 cm−1, respectively [8]. Nevertheless, the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acidities on ZSM-5-M were much larger than those on TS-1-M. The presence of moderate Brønsted acid sites in TS-1-M originated from some defect sites present in TS-1 zeolite [18], where both of the two bridging OH groups are coordinated to the Ti atom whereas only one of them coordinated to the Si atom (Fig. S4). The presence of Lewis acid sites was assigned to coordinately unsaturated and saturated Ti species in the TS-1 framework [18]. In contrast, only a small amount of Lewis acid sites was present in the Silicalite-1-M. The amount acidic sites of the zeolite samples were calculated using the extinction coefficient reported by Emeis [28]. The total acidic sites of the zeolite samples obtained from Py-IR spectra were lower than that obtained from NH3-TPD results (Table S3). This could be because the dynamic diameter (0.55–0.60 nm) of pyridine was slightly than the pore size (0.53 × 0.56 nm) of the 10-MR channel of Silicalite-1-M, TS-1-M and ZSM-5-M zeolites [29], which led to the relative difficulty for pyridine access to the pore channel. In contrast, the NH3 has a small enough molecular diameter (0.29 nm) to enter the pore channel to interact with acid sites [30]. The UV–vis spectrum in Fig. S5 shows a characteristic absorption band in the region of 200–230 nm, which was attributed to tetrahedrally coordinated framework Ti [31,32]. A broad absorption band at 250–290 nm was assigned to the extra-framework Ti atoms in the presence of high coordination state [31,32], which could be TiO6 octahedron [33]. The lack of band between 310 and 330 confirmed the absence of TiO2 in the synthesized TS-1-M sample. The morphologies of three zeolites were observed by SEM technique, and the results are shown in Fig. 2. TS-1-M zeolite had a spheroid shape with particle size about 200 nm, and surface was slightly rough. The ZSM-5-M exhibited caterpillar-like shape consisting of many cylindrical nanoparticles (∼200 nm) oriented along the axial direction. For Silicalite-1-M zeolite, the cylindrical nanoparticles randomly oriented, and the particle size was 200 nm. These results indicated that the morphology of three zeolites were slightly similar to each other to some degree, having similar particle size. 3.2 Catalyst Characterization Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the series of the Ni-based catalysts. For the calcined catalysts, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the MFI structure were maintained well, while two obvious peaks at 2θ=37.2 and 43.3° associated with NiO phase were observed (Fig. 3a) [26]. After reduction, the characteristic peaks of MFI structure were unchanged, an additional peak at 2θ=44.5° related to metal Ni appeared (Fig. 3b) [26]. Notably, the intensity of the diffraction peak at 2θ=44.5° for Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TS-1-M were lower than that for Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample (Fig. S6), indicating that the crystal sizes of Ni metals in Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TS-1-M were lower than that in Ni/Silicalite-1-M. The formation of relatively small metal Ni particle was observed from the XRD pattern of Ni/TiO2 catalyst, and the influence of the disorder on the observation of Ni features in XRD patterns was unconspicuous (Fig. S7, the details please see supporting information). The particle sizes of the Ni phase on different catalysts were further observed by TEM technique. Ni/TS-1-M and Ni/ZSM-5-M catalysts have similar particle size of metal Ni, while relatively large metal Ni particles are formed on Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst ( Fig. 4), which is consistent with XRD results. The highe-resolution TEM image shown in Fig. S8 reveals that a visible lattice spacing is 0.20 nm, consistent with the d-spacing value for Ni {1 1 1} crystallographic planes [27], which testiﬁes that the metals on catalyst surface were active Ni crystals. Based on the analysis results above, the framework constitution element had an influence on the crystals size of the Ni metals in the prepared catalysts through taking their similar texture parameters into consideration. Because TS-1-M, Silicalite-1-M and ZSM-5-M zeolites had the same MFI structure, the discrepancy between them lied in the presence of Ti and Al atoms in TS-1-M and ZSM-5-M zeolites, respectively. Compared with Ni/Silicalite-1-M, the Ti atom in TS-1-M zeolite could strengthen metal-support interaction due to the presence of Ti species. Meanwhile, the Al atoms in ZSM-5-M zeolite can provide numerous acidic hydroxyl groups in interaction strong with Ni species [26]. These are also demonstrated by H2-TPR results of the calcined catalysts. Fig. 5 showed the H2-TPR profiles of different Ni catalysts. There were mainly present two- region reduction profiles for the both Ni/TS-1-M and Ni/ZSM-5-M catalysts. The low-temperature region (255–389 °C) was attributed to the reduction of NiO located on outer surface of support having weak interaction with support [30,34]; the high-temperature region (389–514 °C) was assigned to the reduction of NiO having relatively strong interaction with support and locating in interior mesoporous and micropores of the support [30,34]. As a contrast, only one broad reduction profile centered at 327 °C for Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample was observed, and the reduction profiles in the high-temperature region (389–514 °C) was unconspicuous in comparison with low-temperature region. Comparison of the proportion of the peak area of the high-temperature region in the total reduce peak area, it can be concluded that the average metal-support interaction followed in the order Ni/ZSM-5-M > Ni/TS-1-M > Ni/Silicalite-1-M, which conﬁrmed the presence of strong Ni-support interaction on Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TS-1-M catalysts, caused by the framework Al and Ti atom in ZSM-5-M and TS-1-M samples, respectively, in comparison with Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample. As to Ni/TiO2 sample, it showed one reduction profile with centered at 378 °C associated with the reduction of NiO in moderate interaction with support. In addition, the Ni contents were quantified according to the hydrogen (H2) consumptions results (Table S4), and the calculated nickel contents were lower than the practical Ni content determined by ICP (the details please see Supporting Information). The results implied that partial of Ni species were not reduced, which could be due to the presence of some nickel species that interacted strongly with supports and were difficulty to be reduced, which was in line with the followed XPS spectra. To further investigate the interaction between the metal Ni and the supports and the chemical status of metal Ni, XPS experiments for the reduced Ni catalysts were carried out, and spectra are shown in Fig. 6. C 1 s at 284.8 eV as an intrinsic criterion was adopted for all the XPS spectra. Three Ni species with different electronic states existed in the catalysts. For the reduced Ni/TS-1-M sample, the binding energy for Ni 2p3/2 appearing at about 852.5, 854.4, and 856.7 eV were attributed to Ni0, NiO and Ni2+ in the form of tetrahedral Ni2+ species strongly interacted with the support, respectively (Fig. 6a) [8,35]. In contrast, the binding energy for the metal Ni for Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample shifted relatively high region, and these values were 852.8 and 852.9 eV, respectively (Figs. 6b and 6c, and Table 1). These results indicated that the electron density was highest in the metal Ni species of Ni/TS-1-M catalyst compared to the other catalysts studied. This could be attributed to electron transfer from neighboring Ti species to Ni species, considering the different framework element composition of the supports as well as the XPS analysis for the references NiO and Ni sample (the details please see supporting information, Fig. S9). The Ti 2p XPS spectra of the TS-1-M and Ni/TS-1-M catalyst are good proof of that (Fig. 6d). Specifically, in the TS-1-M sample, two peaks at 458.0 and 460.1 eV associated with octahedral Ti (TiO6) and tetrahedral Ti (TiO4) species are observed [36]. While, for the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst, these two peaks shifted to 458.7 and 460.3 eV, respectively. These results suggested that electron density of Ti species in the TS-1-M was reduced after loading of Ni, especially for the octahedral Ti (TiO6) species. The decrease in electron density of Ti species is due to its special electronic properties, which causes electron transfer from Ti to Ni species. Liqiang Jing has reported that the electronic cloud of Ti atoms in TS-1 zeolite was drawn by Ni species when the metal Ni was introduced into TS-1 zeolite [35]. Generally, the HDO catalytic activity and product distribution of the Ni-based catalysts not only depends on the dispersion and electrical properties of metal Ni, but also is related to the catalyst acidity. The acidity of the catalysts was measured by NH3-TPD and Py-IR spectra. Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst gave a broad desorption curve centered at 267 °C and a shoulder desorption curve at 435 °C ( Fig. 7a), indicating the presence of large amounts of moderate acidic sites and a small amount of strong acidic sites [30,34]. Similarly, from the desorption curves of the adsorbed NH3, Ni/TiO2 catalyst contained simultaneously weak and strong acidic sites, and Ni/TS-1-M and Ni/Silicalite-1-M had mainly weak and moderate acidic sites (Fig. 7a). The total acid amount of the catalyst was decreased in the order of Ni/ZSM-5-M (375.7 μmol·g−1) > Ni/TiO2 (182.9 μmol·g−1) > Ni/TS-1-M (69.4 μmol·g−1) > Ni/Silicalite-1-M (38.3 μmol·g−1). It is notable that the total acid amount of the catalysts was a little higher than that of corresponding support, which could be due to the fact that introduced nickel species are not sufficiently reduced, leading to residual nickel in the form of Ni2+ with characteristic of Lewis acidity, or attributed to the NH3 decomposition catalyzed by the Ni sites. The Py-IR spectra of the catalysts demonstrated that the intensity of Lewis acidic sites in the reduced catalyst was strengthened, while the intensity of B acidic sites was reduced or disappeared, as compared to corresponding supports (Fig. 7b). The amount of the total L acidic sites increased in the catalyst followed the order of Ni/Silicalite-1-M (26.2 μmol·g−1) <Ni/TS-1-M (85.6 μmol·g−1) <Ni/ZSM-5-M (123.8 μmol·g−1) <Ni/TO2 (159.7 μmol·g−1), and only B acid sites (75.5 μmol·g−1) were present in the Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst ( Table 2). The decrease or disappearance of B acid sites in Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TS-1-M indicated that metal Ni preferentially interacted with B acid sites and covered most of the B acid sites [26]. This also implied that the metal-support interaction on Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TS-1-M were stronger than that on Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst. It was notable that the both Ni/TS-1-M and Ni/Silicalite-1-M did not have medium strong Lewis acidic sites, while Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/TiO2 catalysts have both weak and s medium strong acidic sites (Fig. 7b and Table 2). The textural parameters of the catalysts were also measured by N2 sorption, and the results are shown in Fig. S10. The isotherm types of the reduced catalysts were similar to the corresponding supports, indicating that the microporous and mesoporous structure was maintained well. The decrease in external surface area and mesopore volumes of the catalysts were not significant compared to those of the corresponding supports, and the BET surface area and micropore volumes of the catalysts were reduced (Table S2). This suggested that some of the Ni metals tended to block the micropores. Reduced Ni/TS-1-M catalyst showed slightly higher surface area and mesoporous volume than reduced Ni/ZSM-5-M and Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalysts, which could benefit the metal dispersion. 3.3 Hydrodeoxygenation activity 3.3.1 Effect of the framework element on the HDO activity over different catalysts Fig. 8 shows the palmitic acid conversion and product selectivity as a function of time over the different catalysts, where the data was obtained according to three parallel experiments results, and the details please see Fig. S11∼Fig. S13. The palmitic acid conversion gradually increased with the prolongation of reaction time over all these catalysts. Notably, at initial 1 h, the palmitic acid conversion over Ni/TS-1-M (68.4 %) catalyst was higher than that over Ni/ZSM-5-M (47.1 %), Ni/Silicalite-1-M (18.4 %) and Ni/TiO2 (39.2 %) catalysts. Nevertheless, the deoxygenation product of pentadecane (n-C15) was only 8.0 % over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst, which is comparable to the Ni/ZSM-5-M (11.0 %) and Ni/Silicalite-1-M (13.0 %) catalysts. This is because majority of palmitic acid (PA) was reacted with hexadecanol (HOL) to form palmityl-palmitate (PP) with a selectivity of 87.7 % over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst at 1 h. As reaction time was prolonged, PP selectivity was reduced to zero, and HOL and n-C15 were increased over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. The final product selectivity of n-C15 and n-C16 was 97.3 % and 2.7 % at 9 h. It is worth noting that PP (29.3 %) were also formed initially (1 h) on the Ni/Silicalite-1-M, and the PP selectivity was increased significantly (29.3 %→63.5 %) and the selectivity for the deoxygenation product n-C15 was increased slightly (13.0 %→18.0 %) as the reaction proceeded. A similar phenomenon was also observed on Ni/TiO2 catalyst. The change tendency of PP and n-C15 suggested that PP was easily formed and transformed into corresponding n-C15 over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. In addition, a small amount of PP (14.5 %) was generated at 1 h on acidic Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst, and the reduced PP was mainly transformed into n-C16 (55.2 %), and a small amount of iso-C16 (6.6 %), while the n-C15 remained almost unchanged (15.5 %) during the reaction process. This is because the abundant B acid and metal Ni synergistically catalyzed the HOL intermediate, undergoing a dehydration/hydrogenation process to form n-C16. This is consistent with other reports [8,14]. Taking an example for the activity data shown in Fig. S11, it is notable that a 100 % hydrocarbons yield was obtained over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst, in contrast, the total yield of hydrocarbons over the acidic Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst was only 75.4 % at a level of 100 % conversion ( Table 3), which indicated the occurrence of carbon imbalance. It is generally accepted that cracking is easy to occur in deoxygenation reaction catalyzed by acidic catalyst, leading to low hydrocarbons yield [16,17]. Indeed, a small quantity of cracking products were detected (Table S5) in the Ni/ZSM-5-M catalytic system. However, the selectivity of the cracking products was only 9 %. Furthermore, as to weakly acidic Ni/Silicalite-1-M and moderately acidic Ni/TiO2 catalysts, although there were no crack products, the total product yields were only 26.7 and 52.1 %, respectively (Table 3). There should have been present another reason contributing to the low product yield. It could be because some compounds were formed and cannot be detected in the reaction system or trapped in the porous structure of the catalyst, which can be further converted to hydrocarbon product of n-C16 and n-C15, leading to the total product selectivity increased with reaction time. To identify the essence of the low of product selectivity, the spent Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst (reacted for 8 h) was carefully collected, washed with decalin to remove physisorbed product, and then decomposed with HF (40 wt%) solution. The obtained emulsion was extracted with decalin as many times as possible to obtain an extracted phase and analyzed by gas chromatography. It was found that the HOL and PA molecules were present in the extracted phase, and their carbon moles were 0.00036 and 0.00005 mol, respectively. The sum of the carbon moles of detected HOL and PA in the extracted phase was almost comparative to the “lost” carbon-containing compound (Table S6), by taking into consideration that the lost of carbon moles can occur during the catalyst treatment process, containing washing, HF-treatment and extraction steps. Thus, it can be concluded that the low product selectivity (75.4 %) at 8 h observed for the reaction on Ni/ZSM-5-M was caused by the PA and HOL trapped in the porous structure of the catalyst as well as cracking. The spent Ni/Silicalite-1-M and Ni/TiO2 catalysts (reacted for 8 h) were treated with the same procedure used for the spent Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst (as described above), and the analysis results showed that HOL and PA are present in the extracted phase derived from the spent Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst, and the PA are present in the extracted phase derived from the spent Ni/TiO2 catalyst. The Table S6 shows the sum of carbon moles of HOL and PA was 0.00047 mol, which was almost as much as the carbon moles undetected (0.0006 mol) in the reaction system with Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst. A similar experiment result was also observed over Ni/TiO2 catalyst (Table S6). The results mentioned above revealed that the low product selectivity was mainly caused by PA or HOL adsorbed and trapped in the catalyst pores, leading to cover partial active sites, which was inevitable to reduce the catalyst activity and give a low product yield. This is a critical factor for the difficulty in achieving carbon balance for these catalytic systems. 3.3.2 Discussion on activity and product yields over different catalysts Ni/TS-1-M catalyst showed the highest activity during initial reaction time (1–3 h), with a product yield of 100 % at the end of the reaction. This can be attributed to the presence of the framework Ti(IV) species in the Ni/TS-1-M catalysts. The detailed explanation was provided below. Discussion on activity over different catalysts TS-1-M, ZSM-5-M and Silicalite-1-M zeolites exhibit comparable textural parameters and morphology, nonetheless, upon loading and reduction of Ni species, it was observed that the size of Ni particles on the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was similar to Ni/ZSM-5-M, and smaller than Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalysts. Generally, the smaller particle size of active metal, the higher activity of the catalyst shows [34]. In contradiction to that, Ni/TS-1-M has higher HDO activity than Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst. This could be attributed to the discrepancy in electron density of metal Ni, induced by framework Ti(IV) atoms, between these two catalysts. The electron density of metal Ni species played a pivotal role in improving HDO performance. The increase of Ni electron density not only can promote the dissociation of hydrogen and then the hydrogenation of fatty acid to fatty aldehyde (rate-determining step), but also facilitate the cleavage of the C–C bonds of aldehyde to form alkane with one less carbon atom [27]. In our case, the XPS spectra confirmed that the electron density of Ni in Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was moderately increased, induced by framework Ti(IV) atoms, in contrast to that on Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst. To further verify the electron density of Ni influenced by Ti(IV) atoms, another XPS spectra of the reduced Ni/TS-1-M-94 and TS-1-M-94 were re-performed. The binding energy for Ni0 2p3/2 appeared at 852.7 eV ( Fig. 9a) on Ni/TS-1-M-94 catalyst, which was caused by the charge transfer from the TiO4 or TiO6 to the metal Ni on Ni/TS-1-M-94 catalyst. This was demonstrated by the binding energy of TiO4 and TiO6 on Ni/TS-1-M-94 increasing to 460.3 and 458.4 eV, as compared to TS-1-M-94 sample (460.1 and 458.0 eV, in Fig. 9b and Table 1). However, the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst with high Ti content gave lower binding energy (852.5 eV) of Ni0 2p3/2 than Ni/TS-1-M-94 catalyst, which implied that the higher Ti(IV) atoms, the lower electron density of Ni showed in the catalyst. Interestingly, the Ni/TS-1-M-94 catalyst showed lower initial palmitic acid conversion (61.8 %) and the pentadecane selectivity (89.7 %) than Ni/TS-1-M catalyst (68.4 % and 97.3 %, Fig. S14), despite Ni/TS-1-M-94 and Ni/TS-1-M catalysts being presented similar textural parameters, similar Ni particle size (Fig. S15 and Table S2). When the Ni loading was reduced to 3.0 wt%, the electron transfer from Ti(IV) atom to metal Ni also occurred (Figs. 9c and 9d). Consequently, small metal Ni with high electron density in Ni/TS-1-M could account for not only the high activity for the hydrogenation of palmitic acid but also high C–C bonds scission of HAL to form n-C15 with high selectivity, as compared to Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst. In light of the aforementioned XPS results, IR spectra (Fig. S16), UV-Vis spectrum and the relevant literatures [33,37,38], the TiO6 octahedron species could be present in the form of Ti(OSi)2(OH)2(H2O)2 that it is partially coordinated with water and hydroxyl groups. Thus, a possible mechanism of the electron density of Ni influenced by Ti(IV) atoms, especially by the Ti(IV) atoms in the form of TiO6, was proposed and shown in Fig. 10 (the details please see supporting information). In addition, because the disappearance of B acid sites in Ni/TS-1-M indicated the metal Ni interaction with B acid sites and covering the B acid sites, the enriched charge of the oxygen atom in B acid sites that originated from the imperfect TiO4 sites could transfer to nearby Ni atoms. On the other hand, compared with Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample, the Ti species in Ni/TS-1-M can strengthen metal-support interaction and bring about electronic transfer. The H2-TPR proﬁles in Fig. 5 shows that the metal–support interaction on the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was stronger than that on the Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst, which would contribute to the formation of smaller Ni particles after reduction. The electron density of Ni2+ species on the calcined Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was also increased as compared with that on calcined Ni/Silicalite-1-M sample, which was attributed to the electron transfer occurred on calcined Ni/TS-1-M sample (the details please see supporting information, Fig. S17). The electron transfer from Ti species to neighbouring Ni2+ species could benefit the reduction of Ni2+ species. Song et al. has reported that unique electronic properties of Ti species in the Ti-containing MCM-41 (Ti-MCM-41) contributes to the formation of highly dispersed Ni2P phases and intensifies the metal-support interaction on the prepared Ni2P catalyst [21]. Our previous work also reported that the electron on Ti species in TS-1 zeolite can transfer to Mo3d conduction band, boosting the reduction of Mo species and enhancing the sulﬁdation of the Mo species [23]. In this case, the formations of more small metal Ni particles further enhance the HDO activity. Therefore, the framework Ti(IV) atoms in TS-1-M zeolite are responsible for the formation of the metal Ni particle in small size with electron-rich density, enhancing its hydrogenation activity and C–C bonds scission for intermediate aldehydes [8]. In addition, the framework Ti(IV) atoms in Ni/TS-1-M catalyst should also play a crucial role in promoting the esterification of palmitic acid with HOL, which in turns enhances the initial conversion of palmitic acid. As shown in Fig. 8, a significant amount of PP was produced and facilely transformed into HOL and n-C15 over the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. Conversely, although the PP was also generated, it was difficult to be converted on Ni/Silicalite-1-M and Ni/TiO2 catalysts. This could be related to framework Ti(IV) atoms, which was supported by the reactions occurring on metal-free supports using palmitic acid and HOL, as well as PP as starting materials, respectively ( Fig. 11 and Fig. S18). From Fig. 11a, palmitic acid and HOL were esterified rapidly on TS-1-M catalyst, forming a single product of PP with selectivity of 84.3 % at 1 h. In contrast, the percentage of PP moles increased moderately by consuming palmitic acid and HOL over Silicalite-1-M catalyst and was only close to 52.1 % at 5 h (Fig. 11b), and the TiO2 catalyst gave lower percentage (70.7 %) of PP moles than TS-1 zeolite at 5 h (84.3 %, Fig. 10c). The Al-riched ZSM-5-M can catalyze the palmitic acid and HOL to form PP, a small quantity (10.7 %) of PP moles was obtained and the PP was decreased with reaction time (Fig. S19, the details please see Supporting Information). These results demonstrated that the framework Ti(IV) atoms in the tetrahedral coordination in the TS-1-M are beneficial for promoting the esterification reaction of palmitic acid with HOL. Generally, the Brønsted acid sites in the solid catalyst were considered as the active phases in the acid-catalyzed esterification reaction between palmitic acid and alcohol in the reported literatures [39–41]. However, in this work, the esterification activity of TS-1-M is much higher than ZSM-5-M catalyst, even though TS-1-M has much fewer Brønsted sites than ZSM-5-M zeolite. This can be explained as followed. It is well-known that partial (SiO)4Ti in the TS-1-M zeolite can be hydrolyzated to form (SiO)3TiOH under reaction condition, and the (SiO)3TiOH can readily coordinate to an anion with a negative electron [42]. In this reaction, the H2O molecules were formed in the transformation of PA into hexadecanal [8], and some (SiO)4Ti in the TS-1-M zeolite could be hydrolyzated to form (SiO)3TiOH. Carboxylate anion derived from palmitic acid could coordinate to (SiO)3TiOH, forming Ti−OOC(C2H2)14CH3 complex (Fig. S20). The infrared spectroscopy of the PA adsorbed on TS-1-M zeolite ( Fig. 12) provided compelling evidence that in addition to the characteristic CO stretching band at 1714 cm−1 for carboxyl group in the PA molecule [43], another absorption band at 1593 cm−1 was observed. This band was associated with symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group, which originated from the coordination of the carboxylate oxygen atoms in the PA molecule with TS-1-M zeolite [43]. These results gave a clear proof for the deprotonation of carboxyl groups, and followed by the coordination of carboxylate oxygen with the Ti atom in PA adsorbed on TS-1-M zeolite to form Ti−OOC(C2H2)14CH3 complex. In this case, the HOL as a nucleophile reagent could attack the carbonyl carbon of the complex to form PP product (Fig. S20). The hydrogenolysis experiment using PP as starting material was also performed over different supports to investigate the role of framework Ti(IV) atoms, and the obtained results are shown in Fig. S18. Over the TS-1-M catalyst, the PP conversion slightly increased with the reaction time and reached up to 28.4 % at 7 h, and a single product of HOL (16.0 %) was generated (Fig. S18a). It was proved that the remaining HOL (selectivity of 16 %) and PP (selectivity of 18 %) were trapped in the pores of TS-1-M zeolite (the details please Supporting Information, Table S6). In contrast, over the Silicalite-1-M catalyst, a relatively low PP conversion (14.7 %) was obtained and no product was detected in the reaction liquid (Fig. S18b) after reaction time of 7 h. Similarly to the TS-1-M catalyst, the PP was also hydrogenolysized into HOL that was trapped in the pores of the Silicalite-1-M catalyst (the details please Supporting Information). Regarding the TiO2 catalyst, although the PP conversion (67.6 %) and HOL product selectivity were higher than those obtained with the TS-1-M catalyst (Fig. S18c), the PP did not convert over Ni/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8c). The PP conversion was suppressed, which could be due to the coverage of Ti(IV) by the absorbed palmitic acid and the poor accessibility of reactant to active sites caused by the low surface area of the Ni/TiO2 catalyst (the details please Supporting Information). Based on the results mentioned above, the esterification of palmitic acid with HOL was preferred rather than hydrolysis of PP over TS-1-M zeolite. From the discussion above, it can be concluded that Ti(IV) species in Ni/TS-1-M may serve two functions in improving the HDO activity. On one hand, framework Ti(IV) atoms can transfer its electron to neighbouring Ni2+ species, benefiting the reduction of Ni2+ species and formation of more active metal Ni. Meanwhile, the electron of TiO4 and TiO6 can transfer to neighbouring metal Ni atom, leading to an increase of Ni electron density, which can enhance the hydrogenation activity and facilitate the cleavage of the C–C bonds of hexadecanal via decarbonylation path to form n-C15. The framework Ti(IV) species can accelerate the esterification reaction between PA and HOL, and the formed ester was readily further converted into n-C15 under the synergism role of Ni and Ti(IV) species. Therefore, Ni/TS-1-M catalyst exhibits the higher activity and n-C15 selectivity than Ni/ZSM-5-M, Ni/Silicalite-1-M and Ni/TiO2 catalysts. Discussion on product yield over different catalysts The higher hydrocarbon selectivity of Ni/TS-1-M catalyst than other catalysts in the liquid reaction mixture could be attributed to its appropriate Ni dispersion and acidities according to the catalysts characterization results. Comparison of Ni/TS-1-M and Ni/ZSM-5-M catalysts, the significant difference was observed in terms of the acidities density. The Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst possessed almost five times higher acid concentration (375.7 μmol·g−1) than the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst (69.4 μmol·g−1), and also contained numerous B acid sites (75.5 μmol·g−1). In particular, Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst had medium strong B acid sites (40.0 μmol·g−1, Table 2). This caused the PA and the formed HOL to be more strongly adsorbed and easily interacted with B acid, getting trapped in the pores of the Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst. A similar result was reported by Zhu [44]. The OH groups in B acid sites would condensate with carboxy hydroxyl group in PA molecule [8,45], and would adsorb the alcohol through hydrogen bond interaction [46]. The adsorbed PA and HOL would cover active metal Ni, leading to the inhibition of the transformation of palmitic acid and HOL to some extent. As a result, the Ni/ZSM-5-M catalyst had a relatively low hydrocarbon yield of 75.4 %. Although the acid concentration of Ni/Silicalite-1-M (38.3 μmol·g−1) was lower than that of Ni/TS-1-M (69.4 μmol·g−1) catalyst, Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst had a low product yield. This could be caused by the poor dispersion of Ni particles with relatively large size and the small pore size of the Ni/Silicalite-1-M catalyst. The poor dispersion of Ni particles not only reduced the accessibility of reactant to active sites, but also lessened the dissociated hydrogen ability of the metal Ni sites [45]. When PA and HOL adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the low dissociated hydrogen ability of the adjacent metal Ni causes the reactants to remain unconverted in time and trapped in the pores of the catalyst. Furthermore, the trapped PA and HOL further covered partial active sites, inhibiting their conversion. The Ni/TiO2 catalyst has small Ni particles on the catalyst surface, but it has a low surface area, which leads to poor catalyst porosity and a lack of active place for the adsorption and activation of the reactant. As a result, the adsorbed PA had difficulty to convert and remained in the catalyst, covering partial active metal Ni, ultimately resulting in a low product yield was obtained. In contrast, the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst has appropriate acid concentration with weak Lewis acid, relatively high metal dispersion, and high surface area. The absence of B acid sites reduces the adsorption of the reactants and intermediates. The small metal Ni particles provide the high dissociated hydrogen ability, which could be beneficial for the adsorbed PP and HOL intermediates further underwent hydrogenolysis and dehydrogenation/decarbonylation to form HOL and n-C15, respectively. The high surface area of the catalyst offered more active place for the adsorption and activation of the reactants and intermediates. Therefore, the formed PP and HOL intermediates can be converted into nonpolar n-C15 in time over active metal Ni sites. The nonpolar n-C15 was easily desorbed, diffused into the liquid phase and released the metal sites. Therefore, the highest hydrocarbon was obtained over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. 3.3.3 Reaction network According to the discussion and analysis mentioned above, a large amount of PP was formed at initial 1 h and gradually transformed into HOL. To confirm the transformation path of the PP, HDO experiment using PP as a starting reactant over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was performed at 4.0 MPa H2 (Fig. S21). At initial 1.0 h, abundant HOL (39.2 %) and n-C15 (49.5 %) were generated, while only a small amount of n-C16 (3 %) was formed. As the reaction time proceeded, HOL decreased sharply, and the reduced HOL mainly converted into n-C15 with selectivity of 89.2 % through C-C bonds cleavage. This result suggested that PP intially hydrogenolyzed to HOL, which mainly underwent a dehydrogenation-decarbonylation process to form n-C15. Based on the aforementioned discussion and the reported literature [8,46], reaction route for the HDO of palmitic acid (PA) over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was proposed and shown in Fig. S22. The HDO of palmitic acid over Ni/TS-1-M catalyst was involved via decarboxylation and hydrodecarbonylation routes to form the product of n-C15. PA can directly transform into n-C15 through decarboxylation route. Meanwhile, PA was hydrogenated to HOL under a consecutive hydrogenation/dehydration-hydrogenation process. HOL was then either esterified with PA to PP or directly transformed to hexadecanal. The formed PP was converted into HOL under the synergistic catalysis of the Ni metal and Ti(IV) via a hydrogenolysis route. The HOL was inclined to dehydrogenate to hexadecanal, rather than underwent hydrogenation/dehydration process to n-C16 over Ni sites with moderate high electron density. The formed hexadecanal underwent C-C bond cleavage to form n-C15. This proposed reaction route provides a better understanding of the HDO mechanism and the role of Ni/TS-1-M catalyst in the conversion of palmitic acid. 4 Conclusion Several Ni catalysts on mesoporous zeolites with MFI structure (Ni/TS-1-M, Ni/ZSM-5-M, and Ni/Silicalite-1-M) and TiO2 (Ni/TiO2) were prepared and tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of palmitic acid. Among these catalysts, the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst showed the highest HDO activity and 100 % yield of deoxygenation hydrocarbons. The presence of Ti(IV) atoms in the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst played a critical role in enhancing the HDO activity and improving the yield of deoxygenation hydrocarbons, compared to other Ni-supported catalysts. Firstly, the electron of Ti(IV) atoms in the form of TiO4 and TiO6 can transfer to neighbouring active metal Ni, leading to the increase in electron density of metal Ni, which makes it more active towards the good hydrogenation activity and the cleavage of C-C bond in hexadecanal to n-C15. Secondly, the framework Ti(IV) can facilitate the esterification process to form PP from PA and HOL, providing two parallel routes for HOL formation: (i) hydrogenation of PA, and (ii) hydrogenolysis of PP. Finally, the framework Ti(IV) atoms endowed the TS-1-M zeolite with relatively low density of acidic densities, leading to the Ni/TS-1-M catalyst with moderate acidic density of Lewis acidity. This research provides fundamental insights for designing and preparing highly selective hydrodeoxygenation catalysts based on Ti-containing zeolite. coredata.dc:description: Developing a highly efficient Ni-based hydrodeoxygenation catalyst is crucial for the production of renewable biodiesel. Herein, a mesoporous TS-1 zeolite supported Ni catalyst (Ni/TS-1-M) exhibited exceptional hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity and achieved 100 % yield of deoxygenated hydrocarbons (97.3 % pentadecane vs 2.7 % hexadecane), outperforming other catalysts such as Ni on mesoporous ZSM-5 (Ni/ZSM-5-M), mesoporous Silicalite-1 (Ni/Silicalite-1-M) and TiO2 (Ni/TiO2). The Ti(IV) atoms in the form of TiO4 and TiO6 can transfer its electron to nearby metal Ni, leading to the increase in electron density of metal Ni, which enhanced the hydrogenation activity and facilitated the C–C bond cleavage of the hexadecanal to produce pentadecane. Furthermore, the framework Ti(IV) species accelerated the esterification process to generate palmityl palmitate, which was easily hydrogenolyzed to the main intermediate of hexadecanol under the synergistic effect of metal Ni and Ti(IV) on Ni/TS-1-M catalyst. The formed hexadecanol mainly underwent successive dehydrogenation/decarbonylation process to transform into pentadecane.

coredata.dc:title: The promoting role of framework Ti(IV) in enhancing the hydrodeoxygenation performance of palmitic acid over a mesoporous TS-1 supported Ni catalyst
